Topic.Title: Freescale to can its 1.MX7 (processor for tablets/phones) as firm refocuses

Message.Msg: Hey ibbey! You seem to have Omitted where all those highly talented Freescale high-end SoC semiconductor engineers are going next. "Freescale itself is not disclosing the specific numbers of layoffs, but a recent report in Israel’s Globes business news said the firm’s local division was laying off 100-200 of its 500 employees. Sources have also claimed AMD [Advancing Micro Devices] has Hired the team Freescale let go in Israel to take a run at the high end SoC app processor market, though those rumors have yet to be confirmed. Freescale’s i.MX 6 product line has been Extremely Strong, with a broad array of design wins secured with leading manufacturers across a range of application spaces.” Looks like nvidia gets even MORE competition. In the high-end SoC business. From the 200 or so new AMD engineers hired-away from Freescale. Now, this can't be a good thing for nvidia, right ibbey? Oh, no no no.

Topic.Title: Freescale to can its 1.MX7 (processor for tablets/phones) as firm refocuses

Message.Msg: ibexx88, Intel will be a serious contender in the mobile SoC space. I don't think Marvell or Broadcom can really take on Nvidia, especially since these companies don't have too much in the way of "secret sauce". Nvidia, Intel, Qualcomm, Samsung, and Apple will be the leaders. I expect Apple's share to fall off a cliff at some point.

No time at all, boys. Maybe even beating nvidia's long long delayed "Wayne" to market. With 200 new ARM SoC engineers, AMD will be well-armed to take on the team of Nvidia Dawdlers.

Topic.Title: Freescale to can its 1.MX7 (processor for tablets/phones) as firm refocuses

Message.Msg: So Best? While carnival barker ibbey remains fixated on the words about his precious nvidia somehow being a "top 4 player", the Facts say otherwise, right? They sure do. I looked at that highly informative chart from EE Times. ("Analysts clash over Marvell's apps processor sales - EE Times") Which shows Smartphone Application Processor Shipments (millions of units), for the First Half of 2012. 96.5 million __ Qualcomm, THE King of smartphone application processors 65.6 million __ Apple's self-designed iProcessors 29.9 million __ Samsung processors 23.2 million __ Marvell processors (who would have thought, right boys?) 18.4 million __ Texas Instruments (has exited the business for lack of volume) 12.6 million __ Broadcom smartphone processors + on-board cheerleader 10.9 million __ Mediatek processors 4.6 million __ ST processors 2.4 million __ nvidia 1.1 million __ Spreadstrum So Best? ibbey is spewing False and Misleading Information on our board again, right? 'Cause little nvidia has only a miniscule 00.90% of the smartphone processor market. (Just 2.4 million processors out of a total of 265.2 million for the industry.) And is clearly NOT a "top 4 player". Oh no no no. Little nvidia is #9 out of 10 in the industry. Well, now #8 out of 9, with Texas Instruments exiting the business for lack of volume. And Best? If TI exited the market for lack of volume -- and they had Eight Times (8x) the volume that little nvidia has -- why the heck is nvidia still In this business?

Message.Title: Jon Peddie Numbers
Message.Msg: I keep trying to post the Jon Peddie articles without luck. So go check out Jon's website and see for yourself. Great news for Nvidia for Q3

Topic.Title: Jon Peddie Numbers

Message.Msg: Holding steady: 34.3 Million discrete GPUs shipped, 4.5% over last quarter but declined 5.2% from last year. There was a 4.5% dip in overall graphics shipments in Q3 from last quarter. The news was terrific for Nvidia and disappointing for everyone the other major players. From Q2 to Q3 Intel slipped in both desktop (7%) and notebook (8.6%). AMD dropped (2%) in the desktop, and (17%) in notebooks. Nvidia gained 28.3% in desktop from quarter to quarter and jumped almost 12% in the notebook segment. This was a not a very good quarter. The shipments were down -1.45% on a Qtr-Qtr basis, and -10.8% on a Yr-Yr basis. We found that graphics shipments during Q3’12 slipped from last quarter -1.5% as compared to PCs which grew slightly by 0.9% overall (however more GPU’s shipped than PCs due to double attach). GPUs are traditionally a leading indicator of the market, since a GPU goes into every system before it is shipped and most of the PC vendors are guiding down for Q4.

Topic.Title: Jon Peddie Numbers

Message.Msg: Year to year for the quarter the graphics market decreased. Shipments were down 20 million units from this quarter last year. Market shares shifted for the big three, and put pressure on the smaller two, market share in shipments as indicated in Table 1 (units are in millions.) AMD saw a change of -7.7% in total graphics market share from last year, and -1.5% quarter to quarter. Intel’s market share increased 0.9% from last year, and -2.4% from last quarter. Nvidia showed an increase in market share of almost 15% in overall market share from last year rising to 19% from 16% last year. Graphics chips (GPUs) and chips with graphics (IGPs, APUs, and EPGs) are a leading indicator for the PC market. At least one and often two GPUs are present in every PC shipped. It can take the form of a discrete chip, a GPU integrated in the chipset or embedded in the CPU. The average has grown from 1.2 GPUs per PC in 2001 to almost 1.4 GPUs per PC.

Topic.Title: 2.5% Dividend, 15 PE but expensive according to Cramer?

Message.Msg: cramer is good with identifying trends - he may not get them all right but more right than wrong. And in this case he is right that NVDA does not have a heartbeat and is not doing anything lately. I don't agree with his thesis that its expensive at this point.

Message.Title: Cramer's Back . . .
Message.Msg: Okay, just thought I'd post ahead of the bashers on this one. Maybe they are posting about Cramer now. I have so many on ignore, I wouldn't know :). The text from Cramer's show actually states part of what he says in the video. In the video, he states that the stock is expensive when there are no clear catalysts. So the stock is doing 'nothing' during this period. I find that humorous since he has said he likes dividends and doesn't even mention that, and then a couple of calls later tries to steer the caller to buy his favorite tech stock as usual, Apple. He also was referring to a chart of the last three months for Nvidia when he said it was expensive to own (or buy) now. All this on a day when we have news confirming that Nvidia is gaining shares of other tech companies share through Peddie and then separately on a couple of video's about what's selling for the holidays, Surface is at the top in many places for tablets. The irony or should I say hypocrisy is glaring. The real action for accumulation seems to be happening right now actually. Cramer will tell people to buy when the next catalyst is out there or when he can manage to get investors to buy more Apple and thinks Nvidia isn't threatening his 'charity' stock pick.

Topic.Title: Cramer's Back . . .

Message.Msg: NVDA is dead money - no one will buy it with techs all going out of business. No more PC's.

Topic.Title: Cramer's Back . . .

Message.Msg: Buddies, ie Goldman Sachs, yes, I'm aware of that too. But that's what makes his 'show' so much of a deception for anyone wanting a more insightful, transparent call. There was a clear signal with a VERY large options order basically signalling loudly that the stock won't go below $11 through the end of the year into mid to late January and that's when we'll have the first news items on Tegra 4 or at least some possible new design wins etc. I also think if the fiscal 'cliff' is avoided or at least the perception is we are done with it for now, that all the tech stocks will benefit through the end of the year, even the ones that REALLY are expensive.

Message.Title: nvidia's market share for mobile SoCs GPUs? --- 2.5% --- Ha ha ha ha!
Message.Msg: The Jon Peddie Research is out, boys. For the First Half of 2012, the folks at Jon Peddie Research have determined that the Market Shares for makers of mobile SoCs (System-on-a-Chip) with 3D graphics -- you know, for tablets and smartphones -- are as follows. 26.7% __ Qualcomm Incorporated 22.2% __ Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. 21.1% __ Apple Inc. 20.0% __ Other Manufacturers 7.5% ___ Texas Instruments, Inc. 2.5% ___ nvidia Did I mention? 97.5% of the SoC + 3D graphics market is Owned by somebody else besides nvidia. Meaning 97.5% of the market is powered by non-tegra chips. 97.5% Ha ha ha ha ha ha! Google it, boys : Jon Peddie Research—Press Releases Most mobile SoCs GPUs shipped by Qualcomm in first half. Posted by Jon Peddie on October 26th 2012 Best doesn't make this stuff up, you know. Like ibbey does.
